subject: Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: Thanks to Paul et al. for opinions on my questions on dictionary updates. And apologies to Moira and Co. who find the endless technical stuff a bit much.  Part
messageBody:
Thanks to Paul et al. for opinions on my questions on dictionary
updates. And apologies to Moira and Co. who find the endless
technical stuff a bit much. Part of me agrees you.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...>
wrote:
> Regarding vowel changes, I think you have hit on a problem right
off. I
> am guessing that many of the problems will in fact deal with vowel
> differences, so I would need you and others to contribute, but we
> haven't agreed on how to handle these differences yet, whether we
have
> multiple entries, whether we standardize, whether we semi-
standardize,
> or whether we just allow the dictionary to be in one dialect. Not
> knowing what to do in this case poses a problem to creating a
dictionary
> others can use.

The lack of agreement is precisely my reason for holding-off on
submitting vowel changes. I'm not sure that we will ever get
agreement here - group messages are a soapbox, not a ballot box.
Maybe some brave soul should summarize (or summarise) the options and
then create a poll...

It's a pity there seems to be no easy way (yet) to post messages IN
QS. Then some conventions could get established in practice, as Moira
tells us happened in the 1970s.

> My
> inclination is to use the abbreviations, since even though I am a
> novice, I find them quite nice.

OK, I'll submit some as I come across them. In the big picture it
may seem an insignificant step, but we have to start somewhere...

> I read a book called Writing System, and the author claims the
Korean
> alphabet is best one ever invented. But I had the impression it was
> created later than the 15th century. Was it recreated or updated,
or am
> I mistaken?

It was invented in the 15th century, but then supressed at the
instigation of obscurantist scholars. They thought that a simple
writing system, and the consequent universal literacy, would
undermine their powerbase. It only re-emerged, modifed, in later
centuries. Maybe QS needs a few centuries to go by...
